Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Floral pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed (fired dark brown) below; lotus flower and palmette in added red and added white; exterior: at rim, band of black dots; below, band of smaller dots between pairs of dilute bands; below, black-figure floral pattern consisting of part of lotus flower with red, lotus bud with tendril and part of palmette with red centre.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 79, NAU29), the geophysical characteristics of the fabric indicate that the sherd originated in Chios. The sample number is written in ink 'NAU 29' on break, see Dupont and Thomas 2006, 78-9. Lemos identifies the sherd as belonging to a black-figure Komast chalice, however, the exterior floral decoration is not consistent with the decoration on komast chalices. For parallels, see Oxford AN1896-1908-G.115.17.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 329, no. 1553, pl. 198, no. 1553)
Dupont & Thomas 2006 / Naukratis: Les Importations Grecques Orientales Archaïques (p. 78-79, 82-83, fig. 2) (NAU 29)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1330) (phase 2)
